However, data also showed an increase in productivity.“One of the statements in Bernanke’s congressional testimony [last week] was that it was important that productivity continue to outpace inflation,” said Marc Pado, chief market strategist with Cantor Fitzgerald, who suggested that the productivity data was a bright spot for the markets. “You can handle the inflation because the economy can produce more goods with the same number of employees.” At the close the S&P 500 was up 0.3 per cent, or 4.40 points, at 1,312.25; the Nasdaq Composite had gained 0.9 per cent, or 19.93 points, at 2,323.90.The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.4 per cent, or 38.58 points, to 11,438.86 – a fresh six-year high. At one point, the Dow was up 62.80 points, the highest one-day gain since January 2000.The Dow Jones Transportation index touched an all-time high, gaining 3.4 per cent. It is up 19 per cent for the year.Freight shippers Expeditors International soared 18.3 per cent to $103.80, after it raised its dividend by more than 40 per cent and reported earnings per share 20 per cent higher than analysts had forecast.Other transportation companies gained, with Federal Express up 3.5 per cent at $118.20.The market was also boosted by falling crude prices, after data showed an increase in gasoline supplies for the first time in nine weeks. Crude for June delivery fell below $70 a barrel.A buoyant retail sector was led by organic foods supermarket Whole Foods. It posted a 27 per cent rise in quarterly profits, beating forecasts, and raising its sales forecast for 2006. The shares gained 13.3 per cent to $70.42.Among the other retailers to gain from robust earnings reports was wholesale club Costco, which added 2.9 per cent at $55.53 and teen clothing chain Abercrombie and Fitch, which rose 4.8 per cent to $62.26.Archer Daniels Midland fell 7.7 per cent to $40.00, after Prudential downgraded the stock to neutral, citing concerns about the sustainability of its oil seed business.The stock was further hit by news that the US government is considering lifting the tariff on ethanol imports. This followed a lengthy rally.Electronic Arts plummeted 10.9 per cent to $48.55 after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss, and Deutsche Bank downgraded the stock. The video-game maker forecast revenue and earnings well below Wall Street’s previous forecasts.

Titular: Amazon adds soup to its online offerings
Texto: Amazon, the online retailer, has begun selling Kellogg’s Corn Flakes and Campbell’s Cream of Mushroom soup, as it continues its push to establish itself as the dominant online one-stop shopping destination.The retailer’s US customers can now buy almost 2,000 basic packaged foods online, including 12-packs of Campbell’s Cream of Mushroom soup for $12.99, and multi-packs of 70 individual servings of Kellogg’s Corn Flakes for $28.The retailer will also pay for the delivery of most grocery orders of more than $25 – underlining the degree to which it is absorbing costs as it expands its online presence into everything from sex toys to loose diamonds.Amazon said it had gradually expanded the “food and snacks” segment of its online “health and personal care” store in recent months. It said the move mirrored the increasing availability of basic food items at mainstream US drug stores such as CVS and Walgreens.“We look on this as a drug store, and you are going to find food items in a drug store,” said Tracy Ogden, an Amazon spokeswoman.By focusing on bulk purchases of non-perishable items delivered by parcel service, Amazon’s grocery sales contrast with the limited number of online grocers in the US such as Peapod, a unit of Royal Ahold, and Safeway.com.The move also reflects the development of websites such as 1800diapers.com which order bulk sales of low margin packaged items such as baby supplies, creating online competition for discount clubs such as Costco and Wal-Mart’s Sam’s Club.Amazon’s food selection – beyond canned soup – is also dominated by more upscale, higher-margin brands in line with the demographics of its typical users, with organic products from Wild Oats, the second largest US organic and natural grocery chain, and from Paul Newman’s Natural Organics.But its bulk purchase pricing is also undercutting its online competition. Campbell’s Beef and Rice chunky soup, for instance, sells for $1.57 a can on Amazon, compared with $2.69 per can on Peapod, the largest US online grocer.However, one online grocer commented that Amazon’s bulk strategy didn’t seem to present a direct threat to a service that stressed fresh products and reliable and convenient delivery.Amazon offers a range of estimates for delivery of its food items, with the Campbell’s soup taking up to five weeks. Without free shipping, it would incur standard delivery costs of $9.65.Online grocery services have been less successful in the US than in Europe, reflecting lower population densities and differing shopping habits.

Titular: US March retail sales disappoint
Texto: Leading US retailers reported disappointing March sales on Thursday, with bad weather and high petrol prices adding to the impact of a late Easter holiday.Wal-Mart Stores, the largest US discount retailer, said its US same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least a year, rose 1.4 per cent, slightly higher than the 1.3 per cent figure it issued over the weekend.Same store sales at its US stores rose 0.8 per cent, and were up 4.5 per cent at its Sam’s Club warehouse clubs. Its main rival, Target, reported a 2.2 per cent increase in same store sales.Costco, the warehouse club, beat market expectations with a 7 per cent increase in same store sales.For April, Wal-Mart said Easter demand would help drive 4 per cent to 6 per cent same-store sales growth, while Target predicted a 9 to 11 per cent increase.Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics, said his index of overall same store growth for the month rose 1.9 per cent, missing the forecast of 2 per cent growth. He noted that 60 per cent of retailers reported figures below forecasts that already took account of the Easter holiday.“There may be a bit of a consumer spending slow down coming in, with high-energy prices, rising interest rates and a softening of the housing market,” he said.Gap, the largest US speciality clothing retailer, again produced disappointing results, with a 13 per cent slump in same store sales at its US Gap brand stores, 7 per cent at Banana Republic and 15 per cent at Old Navy.Total overall sales for the five week period also fell, down 9 per cent, to $1.35bn.Sabrina Simmons, head of investor relations, said the performance “reflects the challenges we face to increase the frequency of customer visits to our stores”.Teenage clothing retailers, which have strongly outperformed the rest of the industry over the past two years, showed signs of weakness for a second month, according to Retail Metrics’ figures. Abercrombie & Fitch, American Eagle, Aeropostale all reported sales numbers below forecasts.

Titular: Observer - US
Texto:
The heavy truck industry usually values the ability to handle a four-way wrench nut more than academic qualifications.But Dana, the vehicle components manufacturer, appears to be going for that most niche of niche markets: the Latin-speaking truck parts buyer.Since filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection two weeks ago, the commercial vehicles section of the Toledo, Ohio, company’s website has switched to Latin, a move it said yesterday was a leftover from a test site not meant to go public.But the text, from Cicero, reads “nobody likes pain for its own sake, or looks for it and wants to have it, just because it is pain”. Was Dana trying to send a message to its shareholders, who have watched their shares plummet from almost $15 a year ago to just 66 cents?Alternatively, it could be linked to the appointment of Ken Hiltz, a restructuring specialist, as chief financial officer. Hiltz was educated at Harvard and Xavier University, a Jesuit college in Cincinnati with 26 Latin courses on its curriculum.Either way, it was not very good marketing: there was no mention of carrus, Latin for chariot – the nearest the ancients got to today’s big rigs.Costco isn’t giving up on Pablo Picasso.The retail chain says it is looking into reports questioning the authenticity of a supposed Picasso sketch, Drawing Arles, sold for a characteristically nine-heavy price
of $39,999.99 via the Costco website last year.It has also pulled a second sketch, which was going for $145,999.99
until this week. It was supposedly certified by Maya Widmaier-Picasso, the artist’s daughter, who told The New York Times that both certificates were forged.But Costco’s card-holding Picasso-fanciers shouldn’t despair. Jim Tutweiler, the fine art dealer who was the seller of both works, is still offering a far more modestly priced limited edition etching for $1,799.99 (shipping and handling included). There’s also La Petite Corrida, a plate-signed stone lithograph, for $1,459.99, and L’Age du Soleil, another stone etching. Luckily, none of the above require the Widmaier-Picasso stamp of approval.The liberal Netherlands’ tough stance on immigration got tougher this week with the introduction of a compulsory entrance exam for would-be entrants seeking to join family members or marry.The idea is for newcomers to take the test in their homeland so they have a basic grasp of Dutch society and language before being allowed in.Contrast that hardline stance with trends in the corporate sector, where controversial company takeover defences are quietly being dismantled to drag the Netherlands into line
with Anglo-Saxon governance standards.That trend, coupled with the rise of private-equity deal-making, has left Dutch blue-chips dangerously exposed to foreign raiders and bankers.VNU, the market researcher that has attracted a €7.5bn takeover bid, is only one of the companies targeted. Private equity has almost certainly crunched the numbers on KPN, the telecommunications company, and TNT, the mail group, too.Naturally, the homegrown old boys network that has bossed Dutch business for decades, is beginning to look uneasily over its shoulder.So how long can it be before some wag proposes an entrance exam for the business world?The questions could be similar to those posed to immigrants, which include these gems: “Do the Dutch live mostly indoors or outdoors?” and “Is the Netherlands mostly
wet or dry?”.Meanwhile, the simmering US debate over the status of illegal immigrant workers found its way into New York’s St Patrick’s Day celebration – an event known more for green beer and revelry than politics.A group called the Irish Lobby
for Immigration Reform will meet today outside – where else? – an Irish pub called O’Neill’s to protest against expected changes to US immigration law. Their rallying cry is “green cards, not green beer”.The rally, organised by Niall O’Dowd, has drawn support from US senators Ted Kennedy and John McCain. But illegal immigration has become a hot issue in many of the mid-term elections this year and many others are taking a hard line.Ironically, the ILIR is not allowed to march in Manhattan’s St Patrick’s Day Parade. Apparently, there is a rule prohibiting advocacy groups from marching – even if they’re Irish.

Titular: Wall Street lower on retail and crude worries
Texto:
Higher crude prices boosted the energy sector on Thursday but Wall Street fell as soft sales figures from retailers and higher bond yields kept buyers on the sidelines.The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended the session 0.3 per cent lower at 11,025.51, while the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite each fell 0.2 per cent to 1,289.14 and 2,311.11 respectively.Retailers put in a mixed performance as a drop in temperatures and a heavy snow storm in the US northeast kept shoppers indoors.The unexpected cold snap also sapped consumer appetite for spring apparel, putting a squeeze on clothing retailers.Same-store sales figures from Gap and Abercrombie & Fitch both fell short of analysts’ expectations. Gap, which unveiled an 11 per cent drop in February sales, saw its shares fall 2 per cent to $18.28, while teenage fashion retailer Abercrombie tumbled 9.2 per cent to $61.55Discount retailers and department stores provided some relief for the sector, however, as Costco Wholesale gained 1.2 per cent to $52.80 and Kohl’s rose 0.5 per cent to $49.03.Along with retailers, investors also had their collective eye on energy stocks, which rose as concerns over possible disruptions to supplies and the threat of further violence in Nigeria pushed crude futures above $63.Energy service providers were among the top gainers in the sector. Schlumberger climbed 2.9 per cent to $121.42 and Halliburton jumped 3.3 per cent to $71.69.By contrast, financial stocks came under pressure amid renewed concerns over interest rate raises. Citigroup lost 1 per cent to $46,05, Wells Fargoretreated 1.3 per cent to $63.84 and Bank of America lost 1 per cent to $45.15.On the upside, Google continued to rally from Tuesday’s sharp sell-off. Its shares moved up 3.2 per cent to $376.45 as a bullish outlook from Eric Schmidt, chief executive officer, soothed investor concerns about slowing growth.Dana was the worst performer on the S&P. Its shares plunged 43.8 per cent to $1.04 after the ailing auto-parts maker failed to make a $21m bond payment, fuelling speculation that the group might have to soon file for bankruptcy protection.Detroit auto-makers slid on the news. Ford lost 3.7 per cent to $7.66 while General Motors shed 2.5 per cent to $19.41.CBS’s class B shares fell 2.4 per cent to $24.06 after Citigroup advised investors to sell, citing valuation concerns. The investmen firm added that it expected
revenue from CBS’s radio business to come under pressure after the departure of radio show host Howard Stern.Chicos FAS, the women’s casual-clothing retailer, slumped 14.1 per cent
to $41.04 after its fourth-quarter profits missed market estimates.

Titular: Crisis of a lifetime shakes up risk tactics for financial advisers
Subtitular: Strategies to deal with investment dangers now take centre stage
Texto: For 11 years, US investors could mostly treat “risk” as an abstract concept that could be easily traded in for ever-higher returns. The coronavirus pandemic changed that, ending the longest US stock market bull run in history and replacing it with a bear market that throws investment danger into sharp relief.Some investors reacted early to the market volatility by moving assets into relatively safe investments: the first half of March saw large net outflows of dollars from US stock and bond mutual funds and net inflows into money market funds.Financial advisers typically caution that such sudden shifts in portfolios may be short-sighted and prefer that their clients focus on the long run.Even an unprecedented market crash is no reason to toss out one’s entire investing strategy. Advisers note that careful deliberation is vital. For instance, some investors should trim their exposure to stocks, but others should sit tight and wait for markets to recover.The first step is accepting that some risk is necessary to produce returns. For example, US stocks had an excellent 2019, resulting in a total return of 31.5 per cent for the benchmark S&P 500 — but that included sharp reversals in January, May and August.“How we talk about risk has some bearing,” says Chris Cooke, principal at Cooke Financial Group, an advisory firm in Indianapolis, Indiana. “These are really difficult discussions. Because the investments that offer decent returns in the long run may offer volatility in the short term.”That is why a basic tenet of investing is to spread risk among different asset classes that do not typically move in tandem, such as stocks, bonds and cash (also usually diversified among US and non-US holdings). Accredited investors with a net worth of $1m or annual income of at least $200,000 can add “alternative” assets such as hedge funds, private equity and commodities to their mix.Advisers believe that most investors can embrace the concept of asset allocation. “In theory, investors understand not putting all your eggs in one basket,” says Jan Spielman, an adviser with Quest Wealth Management of Storm Lake, Iowa.There are myriad ways to allocate assets, however, and they can be combined. Among FT 400 advisers, the most popular method is to build a “core” of lower-risk, passive investments that track market indices, complemented by riskier “satellite” investments. Some portfolios diversify across different types of risk, including volatility and correlation, rather than among asset classes.And many advisers favour allocating tactically in reaction to market developments, while others use computer-aided “model portfolios” designed for different risk levels.FT 400 advisers typically use an average of three different portfolio-building methods, including those described and others. Retirement investing can be its own category, where the long timelines lead some advisers to prefer a gradual reduction in equity exposure as a planned retirement date approaches, to reduce volatility as the investor increasingly relies on investment income.To tailor for risk, advisers sometimes deploy several techniques for different parts of one client’s account. That is important because many investors like to divide investors’ accounts into easily identified “buckets” that represent, say, different levels of risk. Tactical allocation might be right for a “high risk” bucket, but not for a retiree’s “income” bucket.This kind of compartmentalisation can ease investors’ minds if they know most of their money is in their “low risk” bucket.Ms Spielman uses buckets based on time horizon, so assets aimed at short-term use are put into shorter-term investments, as an example. “I don’t know if I have any client who can tell you how many large capitalisation stocks they own, but they can tell you how much they have invested for different timeframes,” she says.These buckets can make the various investment risks more tangible for investors. Traci Richmond, an adviser and co-founder of the Meakem Group in Bethesda, Maryland, finds that most investors worry about the risk of investment losses but not about other risks such as the risk of outliving one’s savings or the risk of inflation sapping their purchasing power.Like many advisers, Ms Richmond recommends investors keep enough emergency cash to cover at least one year of expenses. Many clients have found that approach helpful this year, she says, knowing that they do not have to sell assets at a loss to access cash.Even though having a “cash” bucket is a good general principle, the specific risk level in every portfolio has to be customised to the individual. That is why new clients at many brokerages are given questionnaires asking how they would feel about a large loss, what their investment goals are, and other ways to assess how much risk they can stand.Unfortunately, the extreme test of recent weeks could reveal that some people are poor judges of their risk tolerance.Of course, the recent market crash is the sort of event that provokes investors to rethink how much risk they want to build into their investment portfolios. But reassessing risk tolerance while markets are plunging may not be a wise long-term move.“People tend to think very short-term, but investing is about managing long-term risk,” says Dan Egan, managing director of behavioural finance and investing at Betterment, a wealth manager. “Investors should only reassess risk with a cool mind. Don’t deceive yourself into believing that panic is going to be useful.”If the coronavirus bear market teaches investors anything about risk, it might be that some people overestimated how much risk they are comfortable with in their portfolios. “If investors can’t sleep, that’s stress that we can’t just ignore,” says Ms Richmond. “But people should wait until things normalise before making any big changes.”

Titular: Costco profits jump as shoppers buy latest gadgets
Texto: Costco Wholesale, the largest discount club in the US, reported a 12.5 per cent increase in second-quarter profits thanks to holiday-season sales of consumer electronics and other high-margin merchandise.The company, which competes with Wal-Mart’s Sam’s Club unit, said profits in the 12 weeks to February 12 were $296.2m, or 62 cents per share, ahead of analyst estimates. This compares to the $263.4m, or 54 cents per share it achieved the previous year, excluding one-time items.Sales at stores open at least a year rose by 8 per cent in February, outpacing Sam’s Club as Costco cashed in on its reputation for selling high-margin items such as digital music players, flat-screen television sets and furniture during the vital Chirtsmas shopping season.Net profits that include exceptional items fell 3 per cent compared to the year-ago quarter. Meanwhile, revenues rose 11 per cent to $13.8bn.Costco also narrowed selling, general and administrative expenses by two basis points to 9.5 per cent of sales, while gross margins, or the percentage of sales left after the cost of goods sold, shrank to 10.75 per cent, from 10.93 percent.For the six months to February 12th, Costco’s net profits increased 2.7 per cent to $512m on revenues that advanced 11 per cent.

Titular: Report from Orlando: shoppers get selective
Texto: Mildred Sjostrand may be the future of the American food retail business. On a warm evening last week, Venezuela-born Mrs Sjostrand and her husband were loading shopping into the back of their car in the palm-tree shaded car park of the Publix Sabor supermarket in Kissimmee, Florida.The supermarket, which opened last year, targets the region’s Hispanic community with a broad range of fresh and packaged Latino foods. It stocks Colombiana brand soda, Publix’s own brand malt drink, maize flour mix for tortillas and several varieties of taro, the root used in Cuban and Central American cooking.“I like the wider range of foods I can find here; there are more Hispanic products – plus, it has good prices,” says Mrs Sjostrand, a local resident who visits the store once or twice a week, particularly to stock up on perishable products.She does not visit the Publix store for other basic items, such as washing powder and paper towels, though, preferring to drive about seven miles to the Costco warehouse club. “You get a big quantity and . . . you get good prices,” she says, adding that she is also a regular visitor to her local Wal-Mart Supercenter.Mrs Sjostrand’s shopping habits reflect how the way Americans shop for groceries has changed over the past 10 years – with a mix of shopping destinations now taking the place of the traditional single weekly trip to the local supermarket.She is also shopping in a market that serves as a model of how the rise of Wal-Mart in particular has changed the regional market. And the fragmentation that results creates new opportunities – opportunities now being targeted by Tesco, the UK grocer, with its plans to establish a range of “convenience” stores on the US west coast next year.Wal-Mart has expanded aggressively around Orlando since entering the market 20 years ago. The area has a greater density of Wal-Marts than most areas of the US – with 20 locations in a 22 mile radius of Orlando’s centre.Wal-Mart now controls 31 per cent of the supermarket sector in the Orlando/Daytona Beach market region where it has 42 stores selling groceries, according to TDLinx, a retail analyst.But Publix, which is privately held, remains the market leader, with 37 per cent of the market from its 107 stores in the region.Winn-Dixie, the regional chain that was previously Publix’s main competitor, has fared less well. It sought bankruptcy protection last year – citing the Wal-Mart effect – and its 87 stores in the region are struggling with just 14 per cent of the regional market.Darrell Rigby, head of the retail practice at Bain, the consultants, says Orlando reflects what has happened elsewhere in the US – with Publix managing to hold on to its market by opening more stores and focusing on local market needs.David Marks of Marketplace Advisers, an Orlando-based retail consultant, points out that Winn-Dixie was dependent on a lower income customer base than Publix, making it particularly vulnerable to Wal-Mart.“It’s really been a two-man race between Publix and Wal-Mart,” says Mr Marks, who shops for groceries at Publix or Wal-Mart.In addition to its high marks for customer service, Publix is regarded as one of the US supermarket industry’s masters of localisation.Its Sabor store, for example, includes a small British foods selection, with bottles of HP Sauce, Marmite and Heinz Salad Cream aimed at local British expatriates and visitors to Disney World.In addition to its new Hispanic format, Publix is also remodelling stores in the prosperous Florida communities of Palm Beach Gardens and Boca Raton to sell natural and organic foods.Wal-Mart, meanwhile, is piling on the pressure in the Orlando market, one of the fastest growing metropolitan areas in the US. The area’s population of 1.8m is expected to increase by 14 per cent by 2009, with prosperous housing developments springing up in East Orlando where most Wal-Mart stores are based.The region is also one of the few areas in the US where the retailer is expanding its network of smaller Neighborhood Market stores. At 35,000-40,000 sq ft, the format is roughly a quarter the size of a Wal-Mart Supercenter, the format that remains the focus of Wal-Mart’s expansion.“In general, we try to site the Supercenters . . . and after that we look to in-fill with the Neighborhood Markets,” says Eric Brewer, of Wal-Mart’s Florida real estate development team.The retailer has four Neighborhood Markets among its 20 Orlando stores, with two more planned for this year. The first opened at the junction of South Chickasaw Trail and Lake Underhill Road last year – less than two miles from the nearest Supercenter. The site is also opposite an older Publix supermarket.The Neighborhood Market, with its architectural facade in place of the usual Wal-Mart plain big blue box, is roughly the same size as the adjacent Publix and stocks the same wide range of about 30,000 items.But in spite of the presence on its shelves of five brands of peanut butter, Wal-Mart argues the format is not trying to be a traditional supermarket but rather a more convenient version of a Supercenter.Publix, meanwhile, is preparing to build a new store on its adjacent site to replace the ageing unit, which continues to draw customers. The store may have higher prices overall but it has its own butchers and bakery counters, and offers complementary coffee, while its staff continue the chain’s tradition of offering to carry shopping to the customers’ cars – under a strict no tipping policy.“Wal-Mart may be cheaper by a few pennies,” says Sigismundo Isidro, a retiree picking up a few groceries at the Publix store. “But I don’t buy so much when I shop. I’m more comfortable at the Publix – I’ve shopped at Publix most of my life.”But while Wal-Mart and Publix dominate the Orlando market, they are not alone at the junction of Chickasaw and Lake Underhill: a neon sign outside the Walgreen’s drug store advertises a dozen eggs for 99 cents and a gallon of milk for $2.49 – a dollar less than at Wal-Mart.Inside, the store has half an aisle of less competitively priced packaged food, including flour, pasta, tins of vegetables and tea and coffee – part of a broad push by the main US drug store chains to win extra business from their customers.Research by Retail Forward, a leading US retail consultancy, estimates that while the number of shoppers visiting traditional supermarkets weekly fell from 56 per cent to 46 per cent between 1999 and 2004, the percentage visiting drug stores increased by 4 per cent and those visiting gasoline convenience stores increased by 8 per cent.This, say retail analysts, is the market that Tesco’s US strategy is aimed at, with its plans for a range of small shops that will focus on the “grab and go” business.However, Publix, Winn-Dixie and Wal-Mart all remain committed to the large format stores with extensive ranges that Americans are used to – in spite of the increasing evidence that more customers such as Mrs Sjostrund are using the traditional format for “top up” shopping.“It is still the most common shopping format,” says Bain’s Mr Rigby of the traditional store. “But customers are learning to appreciate a variety of alternatives as well . . . such as convenience store formats. They are using different stores for different shopping occasions.”Retailers see the pros of convenienceWal-Mart currently operates just 100 of its smaller Neighborhood Market stores – a fraction of its total US store base of more than 3,800 stores. But Eduardo Castro-Wright, head of Wal-Mart’s US stores, says the format will play an increasingly important role in the retailer’s future growth by focusing on “convenience”.Wal-Mart, he said in an FT interview in November, will be “looking at the Neighborhood Market format as a vehicle . . . to serve customers who need convenience for a key reason for shopping at Wal-Mart.”In Orlando, Wal-Mart’s Eric Brewer sees the markets as being for “people who walk in and ask what they are going to have for dinner tonight. We offer a lot of grab and go items, such as pre-prepared meals.”At 40,000 sq ft, the typical Neighborhood Market is about the same size as a regular US supermarket and vastly bigger than the Tesco Express store format used in Europe, which Tesco says will be the model for its US line of convenience stores.At just 3,000 sq ft, a Tesco Express is roughly the size of the US 7-Eleven or Circle K convenience stores that crowd the US urban landscape. But Tesco’s stores sell a premium range of 7,000 lines, including both ready-to-eat meals and packaged and perishable foods and ingredients – something no US supermarket retailer has yet attempted.“I think when Tesco opens their stores, US shoppers will be surprised at how they define ‘convenience’ store,” says Darrell Rigby of Bain, the management consultancy.

Titular: Wall Street follows semiconductor sector lower
Texto: Chipmakers fell victim to the old market adage “buy on the rumour, sell on the news” on Thursday after a rosy mid-quarter update from Texas Instruments prompted more sell-offs in the semiconductor sector.Texas, the second-largest US chipmaker behind Intel, fell 2.8 per cent to $32.63 after it increased the low end of its fourth-quarter earnings and revenue forecast.The fall in Texas shares was largely expected. The chipmaking sector has enjoyed a healthy rally in November on reports of strong demand for consumer electronics goods in the run up to the holiday shopping season.Overall, the Amex semiconductor index shed 1.7 per cent as the other chip stocks also lost ground to the consolidation.Intel pulled back 1.7 per cent to $25.70 ahead of its mid-quarter guidance report, due after the close, while Xilinx fell 1.7 per cent to $26.02 after it too improved its forecast for the current quarter.The losses weighed on the wider market, which closed decidedly lower after having hovered around its Wednesday closing level throughout much of the day.The Dow Jones Industrial Average, fell 0.5 per cent, or 55.79 points, to 10,775.12, dragged down by General Motors’ precipitous 4.5 per cent decline.The broader S&P 500 also backtracked, easing back 0.1 per cent, or 1.53 points to 1,255.84, while the Nasdaq Composite shed 0.3 per cent, or 5.56 points to 2,246.45.The Amex oil index gained 1.5 per cent after crude futures rebounded as cold weather in the US northeast bolstered demand for heating oil.Homebuilders, which have seen heavy speculative activity in recent weeks as investors gauge the likelihood of a bursting of the housing price bubble, found respite in a drop in bond yields.The Philadelphia Homebuilding index bounced back 0.8 per cent, after slumping 2.3 per cent in the previous session on concerns over interest rate rises.Toll Brothers rose 3.6 per cent to $35.55 after unveiling a 72 per cent increase in fourth-quarter profit on a 40 per cent rise in revenue. However gains were limited by the company’s cautious outlook for fiscal 2006.Still on the earnings front, Brinker, owner of the the Chili’s restaurant franchise, had to lower its profit forecasts for the second quarter and the full year after a steak promotion lured in fewer customers than expected.The news drove shares down 9.7 per cent to $36.71.Retailer Costco slumped 2.2 per cent to $48.29 after its first-quarter profits came in below market expectations.Blackberry maker Research in Motion gave up early gains to close 1.4 per cent lower at $60.75.Its shares initially rose following reports that the company was in talks with NPT to end their long-running patent dispute.

Titular: US companies fall prey to religous lawsuits
Texto: At the centre of the company organisation chart is Jesus: all department heads report to Him. Preferred Management, a home healthcare company in the Midwest, is an example of what has become an increasingly common phenomenon in America: employers and employees who bring religion into the workplace.Religious diversity in the American workplace has increased dramatically since a wave of immigrants came to the US in the 1990s. But legal experts say greater diversity has also brought more lawsuits under America’s tough job discrimination laws.“More workers are expressing religious views at work … and more employers are bringing their religion into the workplace,” said Peggy Mastroianni, associate legal counsel for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), the US employment watchdog. Complaints of religious discrimination received by the Commission have risen by 27 per cent since 2000.The war in Iraq has focused attention on cases involving Muslims. But the issue goes well beyond Islam: US companies also employ more evangelicals, more members of African and Asian Christian sects, and more agnostics and atheists than ever before, legal experts say.That had its advantages, Ms Mastroianni said last week at a conference of employment lawyers organised by Ali-Aba (the American Law Institute-American Bar Association). “On Christmas, the Muslims and Jews can work and on Muslim and Jewish holidays the Christians can work,” she said. But it can also cause tensions if employees feel that their boss – or their co-worker – is harassing or penalising them for their religious beliefs, refusing to accommodate their religious needs, or even trying to convert them.EEOC v Preferred Management was one such case: the owner required all employees to conform to her fundamentalist religious beliefs. She refused to hire a Unitarian and required another employee to read the Bible daily as part of a company-mandated self-improvement plan.Employees were asked to share their religious experiences in public meetings and, according to the EEOC, those with “non-conforming religious views” were chastised as being “sinful, weak” or “not walking in God’s path”.The jury found that the owner’s attempts to impose her beliefs on employees violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits job discrimination based on race, colour, religion, sex or national origin. The company had to pay $250,000 (€208,000, £147,000) in punitive damages and $20,000 each in compensatory damages to seven employees.There are also a growing number of complaints brought by employees who claim their religious rights have been compromised at work – either because employers fail to give them time off for religious observance, or prohibit forms of dress tied to their religion.The biggest recent court ruling in this area involved Costco, the wholesaling chain, which sacked an employee for displaying her body piercings at the cash register.She claimed this was required by her religion, the Church of Body Modification. Costco said this violated its clean-cut brand image and insisted she cover piercings with a Band-Aid. A federal appeals court ruled in favour of Costco for sacking her – because she refused to co-operate with the Band-Aid plan.Though the court ducked the issue, the real dispute was whether her religious beliefs were genuine, legal experts say. According to Peter Panken, an employment law expert at Epstein, Becker & Green, courts sometimes struggle to determine what constitutes genuine religious belief.He says the Ku Klux Klan would not qualify as a religion – but a white supremacist belief in a system called “Creativity” might, according to one recent ruling.Generally, a religious belief is “whatever the plaintiff alleges that it is”, he says, but adds that a preference for cat food definitely does not meet the criteria (despite one recent attempt to make such a case).But sometimes, when employers allow workers to express their religious beliefs at work, this can cause problems with co-workers.One case involved an employee who insisted, for religious reasons, on wearing an anti-abortion button showing a foetus. A federal appeals court found that the job discrimination law does not protect an employee who wants to “impose (her) religious views on others.”Courts have split, however, on whether employers can prevent employees from evangelising the customers: for example, by using the phrase “have a blessed day”.Ms Mastroianni recommended that the best way to avoid lawsuits over religion in the workplace was for companies to make sure their harassment policy covered religion, and to act immediately if they knew that an employee’s religious expression was unwelcome to others. But legal experts say they expect the number of such lawsuits to continue to grow.

Titular: Easing inflation fears send Wall St higher
Texto: Wall Street muscled its way back into the positive territory on Thursday with a strong rally after investors took heart from tamer inflation data.All the main indices gained more than 1 per cent, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average moving back above 10,900.The key to the improved sentiment, following sell-offs earlier this week, was a report from the Commerce Department showing only a modest increase in core price inflation and personal income and spending in October.The data revived hopes that the Fed would not have to raise interest rates too high to contain price rises.“Everything today has been spot on,” said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Co. “All the numbers were benign and in line with market expectations. There were no upside surprises, nothing to move the needle.”The good economic news prompted investors to snatch up blue chips such as Alcoa, up 3.2 per cent at $28.28, and McDonald’s, up 4.4 per cent at $35.33.The gains pushed up the Dow Jones Industrial Average 107.74 points, or 1 per cent, to 10,913.61, while the broader S&P 500 index rose 15.35 points, or 1.2 per cent, to 1,264.80. The Nasdaq Composite index, helped by Intel’s advance, jumped 34.35 points, or 1.5 per cent, to 2,267.17.A bullish note from Bear Stearns drove shares in Intel up 1.9 per cent to $37.26. The broker said it expected Intel to raise its guidance for fourth-quarter sales on greater demand from PC companies. The news lifted the overall semiconductor sector, which surged 4.2 per cent on the day.On the downside, some retailers fell despite strong sales growth. Concerns that intense discounting would hurt profit margins limited gains for some, while pushing shares in others lower.Wal-Mart fell 1.1 per cent to $48.03, as did Costco, the wholesaler, down 2.3 per cent to 48.79. The overall S&P retail index gained 0.6 per cent.Consumer products manufacturers remained popular however, with Procter & Gamble tacking on 0.8 per cent to $57.64, while Kellogg rose 0.8 per cent to $44.44.Energy stocks rose along with crude prices. The heavily weighed oil index rose 3.4 per cent, with Exxon Mobil up 2.1 per cent to $59.22.This week’s spike in crude prices did not help the embattled auto sector.Both General Motors and Ford Motor reported double-digit drops in November sales, adding more gloom to a sector which has been struggling with high labour and health costs.GM rose 3.2 per cent to $22.61 - still down for the week - while Ford edged down another 0.4 per cent to $8.10 after their shares slid nearly 5 per cent in the previous session.Apple Computer added 5.6 per cent to $71.60 as demand for its iPod music player continued to rise in the run-up to Christmas.Google bounced back, its shares rising 2.3 per cent to $414.09 as investors dismissed warnings that the company might be overvalued.

Titular: Wall St gives up gains despite bright retail news
Texto: Wall Street surrendered earlier gains to close lower on Thursday, after comments on inflation from a Federal Reserve official overshadowed a continued decline in oil prices and major retailers calming fears over a sharp slowdown in US consumer spending.After a bright start, the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 both fell to fresh three-month lows, with the Dow off 0.3 per cent at 10,284.38 and the S&P 500 0.4 per cent lower at 1,191.13. The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite fell 1 per cent to 2,083.14.Richard Fisher, the president of the Dallas Federal Reserve, once again expressed his concern at rising inflation. His speech reignited worries about tighening monetary policy and its effects on corporate profits.An index for the banking sector, which benefits from higher interest rates, rose 0.4 per cent.Even before the reversal, upbeat sentiment had been laced with caveats. Marc Pado, chief market strategist at Cantor Fitzgerald, said the initial rally had been fuelled by relief that retailers’ sales figures were a little better than expected, as well as falling oil prices and a view that the recent market sell-off had been overdone.However, he warned of dangers ahead as consumers faced higher heating bills and companies were forced to pass on energy-related cost increases.Wal-Mart was a bright spot among retailers, rising 0.9 per cent to $43.91 as its like-for-like sales rose 3.8 per cent in September, boosted by higher gasoline prices.Strong gasoline revenues also boosted turnover at Costco, which reported a 7 per cent increase in same-store sales in its fourth quarter, helping push earnings 20 per cent higher. Costco rose 4.7 per cent to $44.92.Federated Department Stores, the owner of Bloomingdale’s and Macy’s, also rose 2.2 per cent to $65 as September like-for-like sales rose 1.3 per cent, beating analyst expectations.But women’s clothing retailer Talbots slid 7.8 per cent to $26.70 as like-for-like sales tumbled 5.1 per cent in September, with third quarter earnings likely to come in well below last year’s figure.But Guess jumped 16.4 per cent to $24.15 as the clothing retailer bucked the trend by reporting a 14.2 per cent jump in September like-for-like sales.Starbucks rose 3.7 per cent to $51.67 as same-store sales leapt 10 per cent in the five weeks to October 2.Pharmaceuticals outfit The Medicines Co slumped 22.3 per cent to $17.03 as it blamed disappointing sales of Angiomax, its blood-clotting agent, for a projected full-year loss of $10m. The company previously had forecast a profit of $27m.JPMorgan, 0.8 per cent better at $33.73, and Morgan Stanley, up 0.3 per cent at $53.15, benefited from a note from Prudential suggesting the duo could merge.

Titular: Oil prices have mixed impact on US stores
Texto: US retailers largely managed to overcome the impact of higher fuel prices and unseasonably hot weather in September, according to new monthly sales figures, despite growing anxiety about the resilience of consumer demand.Mike Niemira, chief economist at the International Council of Shopping Centers, said that the ICSC’s sales index for the month rose by 4 per cent, against the ICSC’s original forecast of a 3 per cent increase.But he noted that half a percentage point of the sales gain could be attributed to higher value petrol sales by retailers including Costco and Wal-Mart’s Sam’s Club, reflecting the increase in fuel prices since last year.“When I step back, I see more of the same story…it’s not good news, not bad news; it’s more of the same,” he said of the overall figures.Wal-Mart, the largest US retailer, reported a 3.8 per cent increase in sales, but noted that sales increased by only 3.2 per cent if the impact of fuel sales at its Sam’s Club stores were excluded. Without fuel and international sales, Costco’s sales increased by 8 per cent.Wal-Mart also said the costs of store closures and related relief work following hurricanes Katrina and Rita would reduce its third quarter earnings by one cent, while maintaining overall earnings guidance of 55 to 59 cents. Wal-Mart also said it was expecting an increase of October sales in the 2 to 4 per cent range.Target, Wal-Mart’s main discount rival, reported a 5.6 per cent increase in same store sales, and also maintained its $1.50 earnings forcecast for the second half of the year. Bob Ulrich, chief executive, said the retailer expected strong profit rates seen in the third quarter to offset “more modest earnings growth in the fourth quarter”.Among the retailers who reported disappointing figures, Talbots, the mainstream clothing retailer, said it was cutting its third quarter earnings forecast after a 5.1 per cent fall in comparable September sales and lower customer traffic. It said that concerns over the hurricanes and high fuel prices had led to customers deciding to postpone autumn season shopping.Ann Taylor, the women’s clothing retailer, reported a 2.7 per cent fall in sales, citing in part the impact of unseasonably warm weather on autumn fashion sales.Federated department stores, said September’s hurricanes and the impact of high fuel prices had contributed to a sales increase of just 1.3 per cent at its Macy’s and Bloomingdale’s stores, below the 2 to 3 per cent it had expected.Federated shares rose more than three per cent after the company also issued a stronger than expected forecast of earnings for the third and fourth quarters, following the completion of its merger with May department stores.Mr Niemira said he believed that higher gas prices were continuing to weigh on overall sales, despite the relatively strong performance of the sector, estimating their impact at around one percent. “High energy prices are a deterrent to the pace of spending,” he said.* Costco, the discount warehouse club, yesterday said its board had approved a $1bn share buy back programme, as it reported a 20 per cent increase in its fourth quarter profits.The retailer reported net income of $354.7m, or 73 cents a share, exceeding analysts’ forecasts of around 65 cents a share, as it benefited from a tax adjustment worth 7 cents per share.

Titular: Wall Street resilient as energy woes persist
Texto: US stocks showed resilience on Thursday in the face of a catalogue of market-negative developments.Participants reacted calmly to disappointing economic data, rising oil prices and mounting concerns about the effects of Hurricane Katrina, focusing instead on a potential silver lining: an end, or a severe curtailment at least, to the interest-rate tightening policy of the Federal Reserve.By the close of trade, the S&P 500 had edged up 1.26 points to 1,221.59 points, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 21.97, or 0.2 per cent, to 10,459.63. The tech-heavy Nasdaq shed 4.19 points to 2,147.90.The mixed performance comes after major market measures rallied about 1 per cent on Wednesday.On the economic data front, consumer spending rose 1 per cent in July, buoyed up by deep discounts on offer from auto makers.Personal income rose 0.3 per cent, down from 0.5 per cent in June. The combination of rising spending and slowing income growth sent the personal savings rate to minus 0.6 per cent, the lowest level in the 46 years the US government has tracked this measure.Meanwhile, the Institute for Supply Management said its manufacturing index posted an unexpected fall to 53.6 in August.Ed Yardeni, economic strategist for Oak Associates, suggests that investors believe that gas prices and potential shortages over the Labor Day weekend will slow the economy enough to curtail the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate increases.He says Wall Street also believes the economy will rebound when the energy infrastructure is restored, adding: “I agree with this upbeat outlook following the grim disaster.”Banc of America strategist Tom McManus agreed that the prospect of a curtailed rate-hiking cycle was cheering Wall Street.He said that the yield on the two-year Treasury, a sentiment gauge on rate moves, had fallen from just over 4 per cent to 3.7 per cent, suggesting that the market was “betting that there’s only one tightening left”.Energy stocks remained among the hottest performers. Valero Energy rose 2.8 per cent to $109.50, XTO Energy climbed 2.4 per cent to $40.77 and ExxonMobil tacked on 2.97 per cent to $61.68.Another big winner was Chiron, whose shares were up 17.81 per cent to $42.93 after Novartis made a $4.5bn bid to buy the remainder of the drug company. Shares of Novartis added 1 per cent to $49.19.Elsewhere, retailers had a mixed day as strong August sales reports were offset by concerns about September.Wal-Mart rose 0.3 per cent to $45.09 after posting a 3.3 per cent rise in sales, Costco edged up 0.5 per cent to $43.18 and Target declined 1.8 per cent to $52.78 despite posting a 6.3 per cent sales increase.

Titular: Thomson losses widen as restructuring continues
Texto: The exit from its loss-making television unit continued to affect profits at Thomson, the French media technology group, which reported a net loss of €471m ($567.8m) in the six months to the end of June.However, without the losses from the discontinued TV business, pre-tax profits fell by a third to €65m from €97m last year.Total sales were down 12 per cent at €2.97bn, although the group said revenues at core businesses rose 11.8 per cent to €2.85bn on a constant currency basis. Thomson claimed that the total sales figure was not meaningful because of the discontinued TV and other related operations.Frank Dangeard, chief executive, said that the group had put in place most of the essential elements of its two-year strategic plan, in particular the exit from displays and related activities. The root and branch restructuring will see the group refocus on professional media services from consumer electronics.“Our core business delivered a strong performance in the first half, with growth in revenues across all two-year plan activities, stable margins and significantly increased cash flow,” he said.Separately, Thomson announced the acquisition of PRN, a market leader in video advertising in public places, for about $285m in cash. The company manages in-store networks in over 6,000 locations in the US including retailers Wal-Mart and CostCo, and reaches 200m viewers each month.In late June, Thomson sold its loss making picture tube division to Videocon, the Indian consumer electronics group, for €240m, signalling its final withdrawal from TV manufacturing.Looking forward to the second half of the year, Thomson reiterated its expectations of 10 per cent growth at its core businesses. The group added that it expected a stronger performance from services than the systems and equipment division, because of acquisitions and the weak audio/video market. However, there would be charges related to disposals of about €30m.In early trade in Paris, shares were down 2.78 per cent to €18.89.

Titular: Pile high, sell cheap and pay well
Texto: Look!” said the first little boy to walk by with his parents. “Awesome!” the next child, a little girl, said to her mother, pointing at a vast inflatable backyard paddling pool suspended from the warehouse ceiling.At Costco’s Kirkland warehouse located outside Seattle, the pool dangling from the rafters was presumably apparently delivering what Richard Galanti, the US retailer’s chief financial officer, calls the “wow” factor – that extra bit of retail excitement that it wants to produceso as in order to draw visitors be a central part of the appeal of a visit to its cavernous, no-frills warehouse stores.“If we have a floating inflatable ring for towing behind a boat, it will be the biggest there is . . . and it will be 10ft across . . . and it will only cost $49.99,” Mr Galanti says, speaking with rapid enthusiasm in his modest office at Costco’s headquarters in the nearby suburb of Issaquah.But, in the world of US retail, it is not just Costco’s “stack ’em high, sell ’em cheap” approach to higher quality items such as organic spinach and balsamic vinegar that merits solicits attention.In a country the US, where the retail industry has been convulsed over the past decade by the rise of Wal-Mart and its rival discounters, Costco’s discount warehouse club is part of the revolution. But unlike Wal-Mart, whose low-cost labour model has provoked increasingly vocal criticism, Costco has managed to remain competitive while providing its workers with the highest wages and best healthcare plans available anywhere in the US retail industry.In the anti-Wal-Mart camp, “Costco is seen as the White Knight to Wal-Mart’s Darth Vader,” says Nelson Lichtenstein, a University of California professor of labour history, who is editing a new book on Wal-Mart’s rise.Costco was founded by Jim Sinegal, chief executive and president, and Jeff Brotman, now company chairman, in 1983 – the same year that Sam Walton, founder of Wal-Mart, opened Sam’s Club, a his rival warehouse club. , Sam's Club.Both follow the same broad philosophy, developed for small business operators, rather than for individual shoppers: sell a limited number of items in bulk to reduce handling overheads, use mass orders to win attractive pricing from ­suppliers and sell membership subscriptions to boost returns and guarantee customer loyalty.At the Kirkland Costco on a Monday afternoon, shoppers pass the threshold every couple of seconds, flashing their $45 annual Costco membership cards at a staff membern employee at the door.Inside, there are plasma screen TVs for $3,999.99, and three pounds of bananas for 99 cents. There are clothes piled on trestle tables, surrounded by warehouse steel stacks of goods.All this is possible because Costco does not waste money on other things. There are no signs on the aisles and comparatively few staff, no money is spent on advertising, and there is no Costco does not spend money on advertising. It doesn't have an investor relations or communications department.“Anything we can do to lower the expenses translates into being able to sell the merchandise for lower cost,” says Mr Galanti. he says. ““So that we are the extreme value proposition for quality goods.”If membership fees of $960m are excluded, Costco made just $425m in operating profits from its sales of $47bn last year – less than one cent of every dollar it makes at the tills. Wal-Mart has an overall operating profit margin – which includes all its outlets, not just warehouse stores – of around 5 per cent.But Costco’s frugality does not extend to pay and working conditions. The average hourly wage for a full and part-time hourly US employee is $17.41, according to the ­company. At Wal-Mart’s Sam’s Club, the sum for a similar employee same employee received only is around $12 an hour. , while basic wages at Wal-Mart’s discount stores are below $10 per hour.“It’s important to pay people a fair living wage,” says Mr Galanti, “and if you do, and it’s better than everybody else, you’re going to get better people – and they’re going to stick around longer, and we see that.”Costco has a staff turnover rate of 17 per cent annually, excluding seasonal hires, compared with 70 per cent seen in the rest of the sector. Only six per cent of new staff leave within the first year, which again reduces costs. “First and foremost, it’s the right thing to do,” says Mr Galanti. “And long-term, we know it pays ­dividends.” ” says Galanti.While Wal-Mart, Target and other US discounters have vigorously resisted union attempts to organise their workers, around just under 20 about 20 per cent of Costco’s 84,000 US workers are members of the Teamsters union. Costco acquired the union-organised workers when it acquiredpurchased Price Club’s warehouses in 1993 – but, significantly, it has not sought to shun the unions.“We prefer not to have them,” admits Mr says Galanti of the unions. “But we’re not going to fight them. It’s up to the employees to make that decision, not us.”n't sought to get the unions out.Only one Costco warehouse has been organised by the Teamsters since 1993. But Roma Aloise, who heads the Teamsters Costco unit, says the company “has played it pretty straight-forward” during organising drives.“Jim Sinegal believes in treating people right,” he Mr Aloise says of Costco’s chief executive, CEOwho was a vocal supporter of John Kerry’s unsuccessful 2004 presidential bid.Wall Street has sometimes been less appreciative of Costco’s high-wage model. In August 2003, the company’s shares fell around about 20 per cent after it reduced its earnings forecast, amid intensifying competition from Sam’s Club and growing healthcare costs. Costco increased employee contributions to its healthcare scheme last year, easing some of the pressure on costs.The company Costco is also not immune to all the criticisms now being directed at Wal-Mart and Sam’s Club. It rejects calls for independent monitoring of standards at its suppliers’ factories. It is also fighting a would-be class action civil rights law suit alleging a pattern of ­discrimination against its women employees.It also acknowledges shared interests with its rival - particularly on attempts to limit the development of “big box” retail locations. In 1999, when the California state legislature passed a bill - backed by the unions and large supermarket chains - that would have severely limited future development of large stores, Costco joined Wal-Mart and Target in a campaign to get the measure overturned. It spent $2m on newspaper advertising, an unprecedented move for the company, and organised a customer's petition calling for a veto by the governor. “They said it's not you we're after...our view was that its not right, its not competitive, and as soon as you succeeded there you'd come after us anyway,” says Galanti.But, for all this, Meanwhilethe price fight with Sam’s Club ­continues. A few miles from the Kirkland Costco, the Sam's Club in Aurora, Seattle, was undercutting Costco on bananas, with three pounds for just 96 cents. And it was selling bottles of 1999 Georges LaTour Cabernet Sauvignon for $59.77 - 21 cents cheaper than Costco's 2001 vintage.Like Wal-Mart, Costco pursues the goal of low prices with an almost religious zeal. It also maintains a strict limit on how much above cost price it will charge the customer – 14 per cent for branded goods and 15 per cent for its own Kirkland brand products.“We’re extremely fanatical and disciplined about prices,” says Mr Galanti, using the shirt he is wearing as an example.“We’re extremely fanatical and disciplined about prices,” says Mr Galanti, using the shirt he is wearing as an example.Costco started selling the shirt, which Mr Galanti reckons would cost about $40 in a department store, injust three basic colours under its Kirkland brand for $17.99. It was so popular that they went back with a new, even bigger order, and got a lower price.“Overnight, we lowered the price from $17.99 to $12.99. Now, as CFO, I’m going: ‘How about $14.99?’ But that’s not how it works.”“Our view is that that is how companies get in trouble in the retail business,” he says. “They turn around one day and they are their not as special as they used to be.”COSTCO AND THE ORIGINS OF WAREHOUSE CLUB SHOPPINGCostco and Sam’s Club opened their first stores in 1983. But the concept of membership-based warehouse club shopping had been launched in the US by Sol Price, one of the great figures of 20th century American retail.Mr Price, now 89, was a pioneer of the US discount shopping retail revolution, opening a chain called Fed-Mart in California in the 1950s. After selling Fed-Mart, he and his son Robert opened the first Price Club discount store in a converted aircraft hangar in San Diego in 1976.Jim Sinegal, Costco’s joint founder, was one of Mr Price’s protégés, and Wal-Mart’s Sam Walton started Sam’s Club after a visit to Mr Price in California. Mr Walton, who died in 1992 aged 74, acknowledged in his autobiography that he had borrowed “as many ideas from Sol Price as from anybody else in the business”.But unlike Mr Walton, Mr Price was always sympathetic to unions and believed in paying above-market wages, reflecting what Nelson Lichtenstein, professor of labour history at the University of California at Santa Barbara, says were his roots in the postwar order established by President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s New Deal.Robert Price is now chief executive of the family’s latest warehouse venture, Price Smart, which operates stores in Central America, the Caribbean and the Philippines.

Titular: Major US supermarkets downgraded
Texto: Standard & Poor’s on Wednesday lowered its corporate credit ratings on Kroger, Albertson’s, and Safeway, the three largest traditional US supermarkets, citing competitive pressures from Wal-Mart and other discount retailers.The agency said it was lowering its credit rating on their debt from BBB to BBB-, its lowest investment grade.Mary Lou Burde, S&P’s credit analyst, said in a statement that the move was “based on increased business risk, reflected in the difficult operating environment for these traditional supermarket operators.” She also cited difficulties faced by the three in recovering customers lost to rivals during the five month strike by grocery workers in southern California that ended last year.“Customers who had found satisfactory alternatives for their food shopping have proven difficult to win back,” the agency said of the southern California strike.“Although the first quarter of 2005 showed the start of an expected rebound over a weak 2004, longer-term gains will be difficult to achieve, as competitive incursions show no signs of easing.”S&P cited increased competition in particular from Wal-Mart stores supercenters, which offer both groceries and general merchandise, as well as from Costco, the discount warehouse club, drug stores, and low cost dollar stores.On Tuesday, Fitch credit rating agency said it had changed its outlook on Kroger and Albertson’s debt to negative, and affirmed its negative rating on Safeway.

Titular: Luxury and youth support US store sales
Texto: US retailers reported broadly solid sales in May, according to figures released on Thursday, with stores selling luxury items and youth fashion performing strongly, despite high fuel prices and the coolest May for some 20 years.Overall sales at stores open at least a year at 69 retailers monitored by the International Council of Shopping Centers rose by an average of 2.9 per cent, compared to 3.1 per cent in March and April.Mike Niemirah, chief economist at the ICSC, said May saw “more of a continuation of a steady and, to a degree, solid performance, curved a bit by the weather,” while noting pockets of strength in luxury, teen and men’s clothing.Nordstrom, the upmarket fashion department store, reported a 7.4 per cent increase in sales at stores open at least a year, outstriping its rival Saks Fifth Avenue, where sales grew by just 0.8 per cent. Neiman Marcus, the leading US luxury store which is being sold to private equity investors for $5.1bn, on Wednesday reported an 11 percent jump in sales.However, same-store sales at Wal-Mart’s US stores and discount warehouses rose by just 2.5 per cent, at the lower end of its forcast of 2-4 per cent growth. Wal-Mart said that food sales grew faster than sales of other goods, and that most of the increase in comparable store sales was attributable to customers spending more dollars per visit.Target, the second largest US discount store, saw a 5.1 per cent increase in same store sales. Costco, the discount warehouse club, reported a 3 per cent increase in same store sales at its US locations, and cited the impact of poor weather on sales of seasonal goods and clothing.JC Penney, the mid-range department store, posted better-than-expected May same-store sales of 3.5 per cent, above analysts’ estimates of 1.9 per cent.Youth retailer Wet Seal saw a 57 per cent increase in comparable store sales, sending its shares up around 10 per cent in New York, while Bebe and Abercrombie Fitch continued their strong performance with increases of 40.3 per cent and 29 per cent respectively. Federated and Gap both missed analysts’ sales estimates, with Terry Lundgren, Federated’s CEO, saying that cool weather hurt sales of warm-weather apparel such as swimwear and sandals at the department store chain. Gap reported an 8 per cent fall in sales at its Gap, Old Navy and Banana Republic stores, and suggested that continued markdowns on its summer product would continue to affect its profit margins until the introduction of new autumn lines.■ Citigroup is to buy $6.6bn in credit card debt managed by Federated and May’s department stores, in a deal that will generate cash to fund Federated’s acquisition of May’s. Citigroup is to pay an 11.5 per cent premium on the credit card receivables, or about $760m, while the deal will leave Federated with $4.5bn in cash after tax. The two have also agreed that Citigroup will operate the future credit card operations by the retailer, which owns the Macy’s and Bloomingdale’s chains.

Titular: Costco sees faster expansion ahead
Texto: Costco, the US warehouse club retailer, said on Thursday it expected to increase its rate of expansion significantly in its coming fiscal year, with 25-30 new warehouses planned in the US and internationally.“Our expansion is deliberately and definitely ramping up …I can finally say with some confidence that we are going to see some good expansion next year,” said Richard Galanti, chief financial officer.Costco currently operates 452 warehouse stores, including 334 in the US, and has been seeking to expand in the face of increasing public scrutiny in the US of development of big box retailers. Wal-Mart's Sam's Club, its main rival, operates more than 550 warehouses in the US, and about another 90 internationally.Mr Galanti said Costco now expected to add 17 stores this financial year, which ends on August 31, slightly below the 19-20 stores originally predicted, with one store in California delayed by environmental concerns.He said Costco's expansion ambitions faced growing challenges in finding appropriate locations for new warehouses that were “filling in” its existing US network, and was dealing with growing regulatory attention to big-box development.“There is increased traffic mitigation and civic issues, with regard to neighbourhood issues …we're working on more units to get the same number of units opened.“Real estate efforts have doubled, if not tripled, around here in the last few years, but the challenges of real estate have also increased,” he said.Mr Galanti also highlighted growth in sales at Costco's website, which he said had increased 37 per cent during the company's last quarter, with an average transaction value of more than $400.Costco reported a 6 per cent increase in quarterly profits to $209.8m yesterday, or 43 cents per diluted share, with high fuel prices reducing income from its discount petrol stations.Net sales increased 10 per cent to $11.75bn, while sales at warehouses open for at least a year increased 7 per cent.

Titular: Funeral ‘price fixing’ lawsuit filed
Texto: Batesville Casket, producer of 45 per cent of the coffins sold in the US, has been accused of engaging in a price-fixing conspiracy with funeral homes that has cost consumers hundreds of millions of dollars.A lawsuit, filed yesterday on behalf of the Funeral Consumers Alliance, also names as defendents three leading funeral companies - Service Corporation International, Alderwoods Group and Stewart Enterprises - which together operate 2,150 funeral homes across the US, with combined revenues of over $3bn.The suit accuses the funeral homes of refusing to handle Batesville and other coffins supplied more cheaply by online discounters, saying this is in violation of federal regulations. It also says the defendents have conspired to keep prices artificially high, and sought to keep out lower-cost caskets and coffins.Online discounters, such as FuneralDepot.com, have been offering dramatically lower prices on Batesville coffins, threatening both its sales and the traditional margins of the funeral homes. In a sign of the increased competition in the sector, Costco, the discount warehouse club, launched online sales of stainless steel caskets last year for $925, and yesterday launched a new range of light-weight urns for transporting ashes.Joshua Slocum, executive director of the FCA, said funeral homes had conspired for years to inflate prices. “We expect this lawsuit will put an end to these conspiracies, that it will bring free and fair competition to the casket market, and that consumers will be compensated for the damage this behavior has wrought,” he said.The FCA, which has some 400,000 individual memmbers, and a number of consumer plaintiffs also accuse the funeral homes of mounting a disinformation campaign against other low-cost caskets. “Some of the most commonly used lines…include “the handles fall off”, “the bottoms drop out”, “they're made by prisoners”, “they are tin cans” and “they are all seconds”, it says.

Titular: Costco warns profit may miss forecasts
Texto: Costco Wholesale Corp. on Friday said earnings for the rest of its fiscal year would likely miss Wall Street forecasts because of weaker profits from gasoline sales, sending its shares down 9 per cent.The largest U.S. warehouse club operator said profit margins were lower than expected, principally from gasoline sales. Costco operates gas stations at many of its 334 U.S. stores. The retailer often charges less than traditional gas stations do in hopes of bringing customers in to its stores.But with energy prices soaring, Costco has struggled to maintain profitability on gasoline sales.Shares of rival BJ’s Wholesale Club Inc., which also has gas stations at many of its warehouse stores, fell 6 percent in early New York Stock Exchange trading.Costco is the largest player in a warehouse club sector that also includes Wal-Mart Stores Inc.’s Sam’s Club. Costco has won customers by offering luxury items such as expensive French wines and diamond rings alongside the usual warehouseclub bulk items.But the Issaquah, Washington-based retailer has not always been a favorite on Wall Street. Analysts have long criticized the company’s steep labor cost, which have hurt profits.Costco has taken steps to lower healthcare and other costs and its share price has climbed more than 30 percent in the last two years, but some on Wall Street remain wary.“If it’s not one thing then it’s another,” J.P. Morgan analyst Shari Eberts wrote in a note to clients.“Costco’s operating performance is rarely consistent, putting its growth rate at risk. While earnings per share grew strongly in fiscal 2004, it was flattish in 2003 and should be less than 10 percent this year. The culprit ranges from sales misses to expense control issues to gross margin issues.”Costco said it now expects earnings per share for its fiscal third quarter, ending May 8, to be in the range of 41 cents to 43 cents. Wall Street expected 46 cents per share profit, on average, according to Reuters Estimates.Costco had said in early March that analysts’ forecasts at the time were at the high end of company expectations.For the fourth quarter, it said it expects earnings per share of 63 cents to 67 cents, below analysts’ average forecast of 70 cents.“Despite satisfactory sales and membership results, and reasonably good expense control, our gross margins were lower than planned, principally from gasoline sales,” chief financial officer Richard Galanti said in a statement.Costco also raised its quarterly cash dividend to 11.5 cents per share from 10 cents. The dividend is payable May 27 to shareholders of record on May 6.Jaison Blair, retail analyst with Rochdale Research, said the profit outlook was “disappointing” but added that fuel costs eventually balance out and Costco can still reap some benefit from bargain-hunting shoppers.“They offer cheap fuel, and that draws more consumers who are looking for a bargain,” said Blair, who rates Costco shares ”buy” and personally owns the stock. “While they’re there, they say, ‘Let’s go in and buy some crystal or china.’”Shares of Costco fell $4.03, or 9.2 percent, to $39.99 in early Nasdaq trading. BJ’s shares lost $1.79, or 6.1 percent, to trade at $27.34 on the NYSE.(Additional reporting by Bill Rigby in New York)

Titular: HP acquires online photo service Snapfish
Texto: Hewlett-Packard, the computer and printer maker, on Monday said it had acquired Snapfish, the online photo service, in an attempt to bolster its share of the burgeoning digital photo printing market.HP said the move amounted to a ?natural and logical extension? of its photo printing strategy, which has focused almost exclusively on home printing through the sale of the company's digital cameras, printers, scanners and ink supplies.HP's imaging business, widely regarded as the company's crown jewel, accounts for about two-thirds of the group's profits.But intensifying competition from rivals such as Lexmark and Epson have put pressure on the unit in recent months.In addition, HP has been trying to fend off retailers such as Costco and Wal-Mart, which have moved aggressively to capitalise on the digital photo printing market by providing hassle-free printing at lower prices.HP did not disclose the purchase price. Snapfish, which claims more than 13m registered members, offers a range of products and services, including free online picture sharing, photo storage and management, free editing tools and software, online print ordering and more than 70 personalised photo products, such as calendars and mousepads.HP claims consumers can print photos at home for as little as 24 cents, while Costco charges 17 cents. By pre-paying, Snapfish customers will now be able to print photos for as little as 15 cents.?This is HP's response to people who go down to the local retail outlet to print their photos. It's good for people looking to develop large batches at low cost,? said Larry Jamieson, analyst at Lyra Research.HP declined to speculate on how the addition of an online photo service would impact on the company's home printing business, but officials said there was very little overlap among the two companies' customer bases.Market research shows that while the overall digital printing market continues to increase rapidly, home printing has dropped from 83 per cent of total prints in 2002 to about 64 per cent this year.Retail printing has shot up from 8 per cent in 2002 to an estimated 26 per cent in 2005.Online photo printing has remained stable at 8 per cent. Kodak's Ofoto service remains the largest online photo service, with Snapfish and independent Shutterfly rounding out the top three.Snapfish also provides infrastructure services to leading retailers such as Circuit City, internet service providers such as Earthlink and wireless carriers such as Cingular.HP did not provide details on how it planned to expand this part of Snapfish's business.

Titular: Costco misses profit forecasts
Texto: Costco, the largest US warehouse-club retailer, on Wednesday reported quarterly earnings and sales just below analysts’ estimates, marking a change from the results reported this month by other big US retailers.Wal-Mart and Target, the two largest US discounters, along with JC Penney, Gap and Kohl’s all reported profits that beat expectations.Costco’s slight miss sent its shares down more than 5 per cent in morning trade in New York.Second-quarter net income rose 35 per cent to $305.5m, or 62 cents a share, from $226.8m, or 48 cents. Profit was boosted by a one-time $52.1m income tax benefit.Excluding the tax benefit and a $10m after-tax charge for changes in the company’s accounting for leases, net income would have been $263.3m, or 54 cents a share, up 16 per cent from a year ago. On that basis, the results missed analyst expectations by one penny.Daniel Barry, head of Merrill Lynch’s US retailing group, said Costco’s pre-opening expenses were much higher than expected - up 445 per cent, or nearly 2 cents a share - which “accounted for more than all of the shortfall”.Net sales, which excludes membership fees, rose 10 per cent to $12.41bn, below Wall Street estimates of $12.58bn..

Titular: The march of the Geek Squad
Texto: The Geek Squad, now patrolling nearly 700 Best Buy stores across the US and Canada, has good news for the technically challenged: "We can fix any computer - any time - any place."The computer-fixing technicians, who drive "Geek Mobiles" to their house calls, are Best Buy's 24-hour, seven-day-a-week, technical support and repair "task force". They charge a flat rate depending on the service and fix computers regardless of where they were bought.Dressed in short-sleeved white shirts with clip-on black ties and badges, the "agents" are dispatched to people's homes to do everything from removing viruses to installing wireless networks. But the Geek Squad is more than a posse of techies who take being a geek to extreme levels. It is also at the core of Best Buy's strategy to extend its dominance of the consumer electronics market into services.Many large retailers - including Home Depot, Costco, Staples and Petsmart - are turning to services to bolster their sales and earnings growth and gain a competitive edge against discounters, which compete mainly on price. Best Buy, the biggest US consumer electronics retailer, faces fierce competition from its rivals - notably Circuit City and Sears, Roebuck - as well as from warehouse clubs, Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, and Dell, the largest personal computer maker."One way for a retailer to differentiate itself from the Wal-Marts of this world is to provide excellent services, which has never been a part of the Wal-Mart offering," says Darrell Rigby, head of the global retail practice at Bain & Company. "The push to commoditisation by the discounters is destroying differentiation. (Offering services) is a good opportunity for retailers to differentiate from each other."The move into services does not assure success, however. Mr Rigby says that most product companies struggle to make the service move pay off. "They underestimate the capabilities that are required to provide good services," he says. "There seems to be an assumption that people who know how to provide products will also be able to provide good service - the evidence is that this is just not true."Moreover, the organisational structures established to provide services are often flawed. "Either they give services too much independence and don't tie in with core products or they smother services with oversight by the products department who don't understand what is required to grow the services," says Mr Rigby.Even so, retailers that work to understand their customers' needs can be - and have been - successful.
